Sentence	10	The Kyl-Cornyn bill proposal is an attempt to tie immigrant status to U.S. employment.	1
Sentence	11	The legislation would create a guest worker program that would match immigrant workers with jobs mostly not wanted by American citizens.	0
Sentence	12	An immigrant worker would be given five years to come into compliance with an employment order.	0

Sentence	15	The bill drew criticism from immigration groups which include two leading Hispanic organizations because of the "mandatory departure" requirement.	1
Sentence	16	Immigrants who wait five years before leaving the U.S. would pay annual fines totaling $5,000 each year.	0
Sentence	17	Or, after making a  return trip to their native country, they can again apply from there for a temporary job in the U.S.	0

Sentence	19	The maximum would be six years in the United States.	0
Sentence	20	In their home country, they could also apply for U.S. immigrant programs, including the "green card" that grants permanent residency.	0

Sentence	22	The basics of the plan include:	0
Sentence	23	The bill also calls for replacing the practice currently in place in the U.S. of issuing paper Social Security cards with the issuance of a tamper-proof cards.	1
Sentence	24	The Social Security Administration identification card is treated by most states as no form of personal identification at all.	0
Sentence	25	A birth certificate is considered a primary form of identification, along with driver's licenses, passports and other official state or other territory photo-identification cards.	0

Article	62
Sentence	1	On Thursday, Congress turned down the "Net Neutrality Amendment" to the Communications Opportunity, Promotion, and Enhancement Act (COPE Act) 269-152.	1
Sentence	2	The COPE Act is designed to make it easier for telecommunications companies to offer cable TV service and strengthen competition.	1
Sentence	3	Proponents hope it would lower the price of high-speed Internet for consumer by enabling Internet service providers to bundle phone, data, video and mobile phone services.	0
Sentence	4	The act is the first major telecommunications bill to come before Congress in over a decade, and it passed by 321-101 vote on Thursday.	0
Sentence	5	Portions of the "Net Neutrality" amendment to the COPE Act sought to assure that communication companies who provide Internet services treated all data delivery passing through their connections equally.	1
Sentence	6	It specified that each broadband provider has the duty "not to block, impair, degrade, discriminate against, or interfere with the ability of any person to use a broadband connection to access, use, send, receive, or offer lawful content, applications, or services over the Internet."	0
Sentence	7	The amendment's passage would have prevented AT&T, Verizon, Comcast and other broadband providers from charging content providers like Google, Yahoo, Amazon or eBay for priority access to their networks.	0
Sentence	8	Democrats were largely in favour of the legislation with 140 Ayes and 58 Noes, whereas only 11 Republicans voted for the measure, with 211 against.	0
Sentence	9	House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi argued that "The imposition of additional fees for Internet content providers would unduly burden Web-based small businesses and start-ups," and that "They would also hamper communications by noncommercial users, those using religious speech, promoting civic involvement and exercising First Amendment freedoms."	1
Sentence	10	The phone companies and their Congressional allies argued that the restrictions in the amendment would discourage investment in upgrading networks.	1
Sentence	11	Chief technology officer for BellSouth William L. Smith told the Washington Post that telephone companies should be able to charge companies for having their content load faster than that of competitors.	0
Sentence	12	"If I go to the airport, I can buy a coach standby ticket or a first-class ticket," Smith said.	0
Sentence	13	"In the shipping business, I can get two-day air or six-day ground."	0
Sentence	14	The legislation has been subject to intense lobbying by telecommunication companies on one side, and content providers on the other.	1
Sentence	15	The bill is due to be discussed next in the Senate, where lobbying efforts from both sides are expected to intensify.	0
Sentence	16	The White House said that it supports the current bill.	0

Article	181
Sentence	1	The British Association of Dermatologists (BAD) has released a report saying that an illness they named 'mobile phone dermatitis', in which individuals owning a cell phone have developed a rash on the side of their face, is likely linked to nickel deposits in the metal of some cellular phones.	1
Sentence	2	Nickel has been known to cause rashes on those who have a sensitivity to, or are allergic to the metal.	0
Sentence	3	Nickel is also mixed with other metals to make jewelry.	0
Sentence	4	The Association says that the condition is likely to affect people who spend too much time talking on the phone.	1
Sentence	5	They found that those who spend too much time text messaging or talking for long periods on the phone, were most likely to develop a rash, sometimes severe, on their face and ears, or the tips of their fingers.	0
Sentence	6	Tests in January, performed on 22 cellular phones by scientists at Brown University in Rhode Island located in the United States, had found that just under half, a total of 10, contained nickel while the rest had rubber buttons and a plastic case.	1
Sentence	7	Initially the rashes were unexplained, and researchers could not find a reason why so many individuals began to experience the symptoms.	0
Sentence	8	In most cases the rashes were untreatable.	0
Sentence	9	"Cell phones intended for rugged use ... often have rubber coating and no surface nickel.	1
Sentence	10	Those with more fashionable designs often have metallic accents and are more likely to contain free nickel in their casings," said Lionel Bercovitch MD., one of the researchers, in a report in the journal for the Canadian Medical Association on January 1, 2008.	0
Sentence	11	Researchers also state that although some people may not be allergic to nickel, "prolonged" and continuous exposure to it can cause severe reactions.	1
Sentence	12	"Prolonged or repetitive contact with a nickel-containing phone is more likely to cause a skin reaction in those who are allergic," said BAD dermatologist Dr. Graham Lowe in a press release.	1
Sentence	13	In the United Kingdom alone, BAD says nearly 30% of the population suffers from rashes brought on by prolonged exposure to the metal.	0
Sentence	14	The researchers also recommend individuals to buy swab test kits to test for traces of nickel.	1

Sentence	1	The United States Department of Agriculture has announced that a "low pathogenic" form of the H5N1 Avian Flu has been found in fecal samples taken from wild Mallard ducks located in Queen Anne's County in Maryland and in Crawford County located in Pennsylvania.	1
Sentence	2	Officials stress that the strain is of no risk to humans.	0
Sentence	3	Samples from the ducks in Pennsylvania were taken on August 28.	0
Sentence	4	"Testing has ruled out the possibility of this being the highly pathogenic H5N1 strain that has spread through birds in Asia, Europe and Africa.	1
Sentence	5	Test results thus far indicate this is low pathogenic avian influenza, which poses no risk to human health.	0
Sentence	6	The fecal samples were collected on August 2 from resident wild ducks in Queen Anne's County, Maryland, as part of a research project conducted by Ohio State University.	0
Sentence	7	The fecal samples came from mallards that showed no signs of sickness," said the USDA in a statement on its website.	0
Sentence	8	Ducks in Pennsylvania also had shown no signs of being sick.	0
Sentence	9	"Additional testing at NVSL will confirm the pathogenicity of the virus.	1
Sentence	10	These results are expected within two weeks and will be made public when completed.	0
Sentence	11	It should be noted that wild birds are known to harbor many influenza viruses, and the finding of these viruses during routine testing is not unusual," added the statement.	0
Sentence	12	Officials also state that there is no threat to the U.S. chicken industry.	1

Sentence	15	Since 1975, the same strain has shown up at least six times in the U.S.	1

Article	46
Sentence	1	Investigators with the National Transportation Safety Board in the United States have issued an 'urgent safety recommendation' in connection to their role alongside the United Kingdom's Air Accidents Investigation Branch in investigating loss of power in Rolls-Royce engines on Boeing 777s, with the AAIB following suit.	1
Sentence	2	One of them resulted in British Airways Flight 38 crashing short of the runway at London's Heathrow Airport last year.	0
Sentence	3	The NTSB and the AAIB want Rolls-Royce to redesign the engines.	0
Sentence	4	Both events occurred on Boeing 777-200ER airplanes powered by Rolls-Royce RB211 Trent 800 Series engines.	1
Sentence	5	On January 17, 2008 British Airways Flight 38 experienced a dual engine rollback (reduction of engine power) on final approach to Heathrow and crashed, leaving one passenger seriously injured, eight passengers and four of the flight crew with minor injuries and the airplane written off.	0
Sentence	6	The second event occurred on November 26, 2008, when a Delta Air Lines Boeing 777 experienced a single engine rollback during cruise flight over Montana, United States while en route from Shanghai to Atlanta.	1
Sentence	7	Normal operations resumed after the flight crew followed Boeing's published procedure to recover engine performance and the airplane landed safely in Atlanta.	0
Sentence	8	Boeing has already developed new procedures after the crash to prevent ice from building up within their 777 fuel systems after it became apparent that icing may have been a factor, and it was some of these that the Delta flight crew had followed.	1
Sentence	9	Boeing modified these further after the Delta incident.	0
Sentence	10	As part of the recent releases by the NTSB and AAIB it has become apparent that investigators from both bodies, which are collaborating, have found ice buildup in the fuel system caused both rollbacks.	0
Sentence	11	In both cases a build-up of ice (from water normally present in all jet fuel) developed on a component called the fuel/oil heat exchanger.	1
Sentence	12	This restricted the flow of fuel to the engine, resulting in the uncommanded engine rollback.	0
Sentence	13	Investigators initially struggled to produce enough ice under test conditions but have now found that at high concentration, fuel can form ice at very low temperatures in enough quantity to seriously restrict fuel flow, according to a new interim report by the AAIB.	0
Sentence	14	This does not occur when fuel demand is lower, as the hot oil then becomes sufficient to entirely melt the ice.	0
Sentence	15	The British jet experienced very low temperatures over Siberia.	0
Sentence	16	The vigorous tests are thought to be the first of their kind.	1
Sentence	17	They have also confirmed that while ice may have formed elsewhere in the airliner's fuel system fuel was probably not restricted at any other location.	0
Sentence	18	Instead, it is thought 'soft' ice formed in the pipes and then broke off, travelling to the fuel/oil heat exchanger and restricting it.	0
Sentence	19	The NTSB has now revealed that they have advised Rolls-Royce to redesign the fuel/oil heat exchanger, and Rolls-Royce have stated that they are indeed working on a replacement part that will be available within twelve months.	1
Sentence	20	The AAIB advised Boeing and Rolls-Royce to jointly review the problem across the fuel system, and both companies responded that they 'accepted' this recommendation and repeated that a replacement part was being developed.	0
Sentence	21	Both the NTSB and the AAIB also sent letters to the US Federal Aviation Administration and the European Aviation Safety Agency requesting the installment of the modified component be mandatory.	1
Sentence	22	The NTSB suggested this should be either the next maintenance check or within six months.	0
Sentence	23	There are 220 Boeing 777-200s - the only type using the affected engine - with Trent 800 series engines.	0
Sentence	24	The fuel/oil heat exchanger is a dual purpose part designed to simultaneously melt fuel ice and cool down engine oil.	1
Sentence	25	The AAIB further noted that it is unclear weather other aircraft designs are at risk, and advised the FAA and EASA to look into increased use of de-icing additives and investigate both the accumulation and sudden movement of ice in aircraft fuel systems and the actual formation of ice in the fuel itself.	1

Sentence	23	However, "Chronic fiscal imbalances" — failing to address excessive government debt, and "Severe income disparity" — a widening of the the gulf between rich and poor, top the list of most likely risks.	1
Sentence	24	At the other end of the tables, disagreeing respectively with the weight last year's Wikinews report gave to orbital debris, and the Motion Picture Association of America's (MPAA) fight with the Internet over copyright legislation, the 2012 Global Risks Report places "Proliferation of Orbital Debris" and "Failure of intellectual property regime" bottom of the league in terms of potential impact.	1
Sentence	25	In 2011, with the current global economic crisis well under-way, "Fiscal crises" topped the WEF risks with the largest potential impact in the next ten years.	1
Sentence	26	However, perceived as most likely a year ago, "Storms and cyclones", "Flooding", and "Biodiversity loss" — all climate-change related points — were placed ahead of "Economic disparity" and "Fiscal crises".	0
Sentence	27	More mundane risks overtake the spectre of terrorism when contrasting this year's report with the 2011 one; volatility in the prices of commodities, consumer goods, and energy, and the security of water supplies are all now ranked as more likely risks than terrorism — though the 2011 report did rank some of these concerns as having a higher potential impact.	1
Sentence	28	A significant shift in perception sees the 2012 report highlight food shortages almost as likely a risk the world will face over the next decade; and, one with a far more significant impact.	0

Sentence	1	Commander Ali Dizaei of London's Metropolitan Police Service today became the most senior officer anywhere in the United Kingdom to be convicted of offences by a court.	1
Sentence	2	Dizaei, who was branded a "criminal in uniform" by Independent Police Complaints Commission chair Nick Hardwick, has been jailed for four years after he attempted to frame an Iraqi businessman.	0
Sentence	3	It took a Southwark Crown Court jury under three hours to find Dizaei guilty of misconduct in a public office and attempting to pervert the course of justice.	1
Sentence	4	The charges carried a maximum of life imprisonment.	0

Sentence	6	They then went to their car and struck up a conversation through its open window with the restaurant's manager.	0

Article	153
Sentence	1	Thirty-six years after he was found guilty of an armed robbery in London, a court has quashed the conviction of George Davis, ruling it unsafe.	1
Sentence	2	The court stopped short of ruling he was definitely innocent, leaving a prominent 1970s campaign that saw "George Davis is innocent - OK" graffiti daubed across the city only partially vindicated.	0
Sentence	3	The case dates back to April 1974, when armed robbers raided the London Electricity Board.	1
Sentence	4	A police officer was wounded by a gunshot to the leg.	0
Sentence	5	Davis was one of four put on trial the following year, but only he was convicted following two policemen who witnessed the robbery.	0
Sentence	6	He received twenty years imprisonment for wounding and armed robbery.	0
Sentence	7	By 1976 he was back out of prison with a Royal Pardon after doubts about his identification were raised by then-Home Secretary Roy Jenkins.	1
Sentence	8	The 1970s saw the slogan "George Davis is innocent - OK" written across bridges and buildings around the capital, some of which remains today.	0
Sentence	9	Support came from The Who frontman Roger Daltrey, who wore a t-shirt promoting his case, and punk band Sham 69 writing a song about it.	0
Sentence	10	One incident saw a cricket pitch vandalised in 1975, leading to the abandonment of an Ashes Test match in its final day at Headingley.	1
Sentence	11	By 1977, however, Davis was back in prison and admitted a role in a different armed robbery, at a Bank of Cyprus branch.	0
Sentence	12	"I have been protesting my innocence since 1974," Davis said yesterday.	1
Sentence	13	Lawyers have said evidence that should have overturned the 1975 conviction "had been in the hands of the authorities since 1977."	0
Sentence	14	Following the conviction the case was reviewed by Detective Chief Superintendent Jack Moulder from Hertfordshire Police, who reported back to the Home Office in 1977.	1
Sentence	15	Journalist Andy McSmith, writing in The Independent, claims the result "was so damning that for 34 years the Home Office refused to let anyone, including Davis's lawyers, see it."	0
Sentence	16	Moulder's report drew on evidence from Inspector Brian Reynolds, who began the investigation into the robbery before responsibility was passed to the specialist Robbery Squad.	1
Sentence	17	Reynolds had criticisms of the Robbery Squad, but said senior officers warned him not to obstruct Davis's conviction in any way.	0
Sentence	18	The Robbery Squad was being led by Jack Slipper, whose claim to fame is that he tracked down the Great Train Robbers.	0
Sentence	19	The Criminal Cases Review Commission, which investigates alleged miscarriages of justice, collected evidence in the Davis case and referred it back to the Court of Appeal.	1
Sentence	20	36 years ago, a young barrister called David Whitehouse defended Davis.	0
Sentence	21	Yesterday, Whitehouse's last day in court before retiring was in the Court of Appeal, hearing Davis's conviction overturned.	0
Sentence	22	"If George Davis had not been so stupid as to rob a bank I might have got the conviction quashed [in the 70s]," he remarked outside court.	1
Sentence	23	Asked about being called stupid, Davis remarked "He can call me what he likes after [all] he's done for me."	0
Sentence	24	The appeal was heard by a panel of three judges.	1
Sentence	25	Lord Justice Hughes said they were in a "state of ignorance whether or not the defendant committed this robbery and we are unable positively to exonerate him".	0
Sentence	26	"We do not know whether Davis was guilty or not, but his conviction cannot be said to be safe," Hughes concluded.	0
Sentence	27	"I have pursued this appeal for all these years because I wanted all those people who worked for, and helped, the campaign in the 1970s to know that their support was justified," Davis said.	1

Sentence	4	This includes setting, for industrialized nations, targets for reductions of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.	0
Sentence	5	Numerous observers and parties had voiced that they see this as being of great importance prior to and during the conference.	0
Sentence	6	Following the reopening of the plenary at midday, India reiterated its position that part of a paragraph needed to be reformulated.	1
Sentence	7	The EU went on to state that in the spirit of negotiations, they agreed with the proposed changes.	0
Sentence	8	After some further statements by other nations, the US said that they can not accept the changes, as they would considerably change the balance of the text.	0
Sentence	9	This was met with loudly audible booing in the plenary.	0
Sentence	10	Some time later, after a number of other nations voiced their opinions and the American delegation could be seen busily debating and writing, the US said they would agree to the consensus position after all.	0
Sentence	11	Standing ovations and cheers welcomed this change in position, which allowed the President of the Conference soon thereafter to declare the document decided.	0
Sentence	12	India this morning had raised objections on one of the central documents of what constitutes the Roadmap.	1
Sentence	13	This had made a decision impossible for the time being, as the conference can only pass items unanimously.	0
Sentence	14	The objection regarded the phrasing of how nations with developing industries are to take action to slow and reduce their GHG emissions.	0
Sentence	15	The President of the Conference, the Indonesian Environmental Minister, had declined the request, stating that the proposal he had made was very finely balanced.	0
Sentence	16	The President had then suspended the session so that further consultations could be made.	0
Sentence	17	No progress was made when the meeting was reopened about an hour later, with China stating that negotiations of the so called Group of 77 and China with the Indonesian Minister of Finance were still ongoing.	1
Sentence	18	China then accused the UNFCCC secretariat of deliberately opening the plenary session at a time it knew that their Ministers were in talks.	0
Sentence	19	The Chinese delegate went on to demand an apology by the secretariat, and the meeting was again suspended.	0
Sentence	20	Ministerial negotiations had continued through the night until the early morning hours yesterday and the climate conference had been scheduled to decide on the last outstanding items this morning.	1
Sentence	21	Yesterday evening Yvo de Boer of the UNFCCC had said that the parties were "on the brink of agreement", when he was asked where negotiations currently stand.	1
Sentence	22	With almost all open matters having been agreed on by a group of 40 ministers, one of the last outstanding points then was still the question of guideline numbers for GHG cuts.	0
Sentence	23	Some of the issues that had still been open the day before yesterday (for example how deforestation was to be addressed and the matter of financial support for developing countries to send and support negotiators to the UN climate conferences), had apparently been addressed to everyones satisfaction during yesterdays informal talks.	1
Sentence	24	But the talks were still on with regard to preambular text of a document that states how further action to mitigate climate change is to be taken, the inclusion of a 25-40% range for reductions in GHG emissions for industrialized nations by 2020 from 1990 levels being contested.	0
Sentence	25	The draft decision proposed by the President of the Conference today however, no longer included the numbers, but did make reference to the latest report by the international body of scientists that is charged with assessing the current state of knowledge on climate change.	1
Sentence	26	This Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) had presented its Synthesis report earlier this year.	0

Sentence	4	Critics, including Google, Yahoo, search engine Yandex and social networking site Vkontakte noted that as-written the legislation contained many technical faults likely to negatively impact legitimate internet use.	1

Sentence	6	The blackout banner includes the text: "Imagine a world without free knowledge", and summarises the details of the bill.	0
Sentence	7	Readers are warned that articles, such as Suicide, may be considered "harmful" due to ambiguity in the proposed legislation, risking a block of the entire website by Russia-based Internet providers.	0

Sentence	9	The announcement by the Russian Wikimedia community states:	1
Sentence	10	Supporters of the law proposed say that it is aimed only at widely prohibited content such as child pornography and «information like this», but conditions for determining the content falling under this law will create a thing like the «great Chinese firewall».	1
Sentence	11	The existing Russian law's practice shows the high possibility of the worst scenario, in which access to Wikipedia soon will be closed in the country.	0
Sentence	12	On July 11 the second reading of the law in the State Duma will take place.	1
Sentence	13	The law will come into force after the third reading, for which a date has not yet been set.	0

Sentence	3	The program, called  SBInet, will have $50 million from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 that was allocated to it withdrawn in favor of investment in other, immediately available technology for the purposes of security along the border.	1
Sentence	4	The program will also have all further funding immediately frozen; as a result, all work will halt on the project beyond two small test projects in Arizona.	0
Sentence	5	Officially, the move is in light of a pending reassessment of the program, though it is likely that it signals the end of the five-year project, which has come under mounting criticism based on cost and the time taken to complete the project.	0
Sentence	6	In a statement, Napolitano said that, "effective immediately, the Department of Homeland Security will redeploy $50 million of Recovery Act funding originally allocated for the SBInet...to other tested, commercially available security technology along the Southwest border."	1
Sentence	7	Criticism of the project has been largely based on the cost, which has been commented on by several government officials, including Senator John McCain, who criticized the program as "spending over $1 billion of taxpayers' dollars on a failed system of sensors and cameras."	1
Sentence	8	According to statements released last year, at the beginning of construction, the project would cost a total of $6.7 billion, of which $3.4 billion has been spent on the first phase of the plan.	0
Sentence	9	The shortcomings were acknowledged by Napolitano in her statement, which said that "the system of sensors and cameras along the Southwest border known as SBInet has been plagued with cost overruns and missed deadlines."	0
Sentence	10	The project was originally introduced in 2006 by President George W. Bush, and was envisioned as a high-tech system, dubbed a "virtual fence," that combined cameras, radar, and sensors to allow the Border Patrol to intercept up to 85% of incursions with as few as 22,000 officers.	1
Sentence	11	The contract was awarded to Boeing, which has since come under criticism for developing costly new technologies rather than using off-the-shelf systems.	0
Sentence	12	Under Barack Obama, the government initially continued to support the program, and laid out a new timetable for the its completion.	0
Sentence	13	Last month, however, under questioning from Congress about the program's viability, the administration reduced funding to complete the first phase by 30%, to $574 million.	0

Article	109
Sentence	1	 The definition of what is and what is not a planet is being challenged by a newly announced discovery Friday.	1
Sentence	2	Astronomers from the Palomar Observatory near San Diego, California said they found a chunk of ice and rock in the solar system larger than Pluto.	0
Sentence	3	The object, given the temporary generic name of 2003 UB313, is about 9 billion miles away from the sun.	1
Sentence	4	It was first photographed in 2003 using the Gemini Observatory in Hawaii.	0
Sentence	5	But it was an indistinguishable bright spot among a field of stars in an area of the sky where astronomers don't usually look at for planets or planet-type objects.	0
Sentence	6	Solar system bodies found beyond the orbit of Neptune are called "trans-Neptunian objects".	1
Sentence	7	One of them, Pluto, is also classified as a planet.	0
Sentence	8	Up until now all other planet-like discoveries beyond Neptune, including Sedna, found by the same Palomar team in 2004, are called Kuiper Belt objects, or minor planets.	0
Sentence	9	Using a photo taken on January 8, the Palomar team compared it with previous 2003 UB313 photos to triangulate the object's distance, brightness and orbit.	1
Sentence	10	Using mathematical formulas, they found a range of sizes for 2003 UB313, with an estimated average showing the approximate diameter of the new body to be about 2,600 kilometers.	1
Sentence	11	But even at the smallest estimate scientists are certain 2003 UB313 is larger than Pluto's 2,250 kilometer diameter.	0
Sentence	12	To determine size, Scientists deduce the relative size of a solar system object by its brightness, just as one can infer the size of a faraway light bulb if one knows its wattage.	1
Sentence	13	The reflectance of 2003 UB313 is not yet known for sure.	0
Sentence	14	Scientists can not yet tell how much light from the sun is reflected away from its surface, but the amount of light the planet does reflect puts a lower limit on its size.	0
Sentence	15	"Even if it reflected 100 percent of the light reaching it, it would still be as big as Pluto," Michael E. Brown, a professor of planetary astronomy at the California Institute of Technology said in a NASA press release.	1
Sentence	16	"I'd say it's probably one and a half times the size of Pluto, but we're not sure yet of the final size."	0
Sentence	17	"We are 100 percent confident that this is the first object bigger than Pluto ever found in the outer solar system," Brown added.	1
Sentence	18	The object is inclined by a whopping 45 degrees to the main plane of the solar system, where most of the other planets orbit.	1
Sentence	19	That's why it eluded discovery: nobody was looking there until now, Brown said.	0
Sentence	20	Most objects in the solar system are just a few degrees from the main plane of the solar system, called the Ecliptic.	1
Sentence	21	Pluto, which is considered substantially different from the rest of the planets, is only 17 degrees from this main plane.	0
Sentence	22	Astronomers who study the sky for asteroids and comets usually look in the region of the sky that the rest of the planets occupy.	0
Sentence	23	The brightness of this object is just barely fainter than the telescopes from earlier sky surveys were able to identify, so new advances in the making of telescopes has also played a part in this discovery.	1
Sentence	24	Now that the discovery data has been released, the scientists will turn over their work to the International Astronomical Union (IAU), which will review it, classify the object and approve a new name to replace the temporary 2003 UB313.	1
Sentence	25	Sometimes the discoverers of a new planetary body get to choose its name, but not always.	1
Sentence	26	"We have a name we really like, and we want it to stick," Brown told reporters at a press conference.	0
Sentence	27	He said the team has submitted the name to the IAU but would not disclose their choice.	0
Sentence	28	In the 2004 naming of Sedna, Brown noted objects found in the Kuiper Belt are usually named after deities of the Underworld.	0
Sentence	29	The astronomers have been using a code name of sorts for the discovery.	1
Sentence	30	The tongue-in-cheek nickname  is "Xena" after the fictional main character of the television series of the same name.	0
Sentence	31	"Because we always wanted to name something Xena," Dr. Brown said in a New York Times report.	0
Sentence	32	There has been controversy in the scientific community about what is and what is not a planet.	1
Sentence	33	Some purists insist the Solar system has only eight planets and that Kuiper Belt object including Pluto, Sedna and 2003 UB313 cannot be listed among the major planets.	0
Sentence	34	A minor furor erupted when the IAU suggested removing Pluto from the pantheon of planets a few years ago.	1
Sentence	35	Because of that Pluto's status as a "planet" in addition to being a Kuiper Belt object was cemented.	0
Sentence	36	But with the discovery of 2003 UB313 the "planet or not" debate may rekindle.	0
Sentence	37	"Pluto has been a planet for so long that the world is comfortable with that," Brown said in the teleconference.	1
Sentence	38	"It seems to me a logical extension that anything bigger than Pluto and farther out is a planet."	0
Sentence	39	Offering additional justification, Brown said 2003 UB313 appears to be surfaced with methane ice, as is Pluto.	1
Sentence	40	That's not the case with other large Kuiper Belt objects, however.	0
Sentence	41	"This object is in a class very much like Pluto," he said.	1
Sentence	42	The new "10th planet" was not the only new discovery in the Kuiper Belt this past week.	1
Sentence	43	José-Luis Ortiz at the Sierra Nevada Observatory in Spain announced the discovery of an object called 2003 EL61.	0
Sentence	44	This object, thought to be larger than Sedna, is the brightest trans-Neptune object next to Pluto.	0
Sentence	45	Although some news media confused the discovery of 2003 EL61 with 2003 UB313, they are different objects.	1
Sentence	46	2003 EL61 is so bright, it can be seen with high-end amateur-grade telescopes equipped with CCD cameras.	1
Sentence	47	Although this second discovery may not be as large as 2003 UB313, scientists have confirmed that 2003 EL61 has its own moon.	0

Sentence	2	The Lexus HS 250h model was subjected to the recall following a US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) investigation.	1
Sentence	3	Despite previously passing Toyota safety inspections, the conclusions of an NHTSA sub-contracted investigator were that; when the vehicles in question collided with an object at more than fifty-miles-per hour, more than 142 grams of fuel, the maximum allowed by US law, leaked from the crashed car.	0
Sentence	4	According to Toyota, further tests did not show any additional failure of the fuel tank.	1
Sentence	5	In response to the findings, Toyota issued a recall of all affected vehicles, since the company had no solution immediately available.	1

Article	49
Sentence	1	Anita O'Day, best known for her sassy rendition of "Sweet Georgia Brown" and "Honeysuckle Rose" died in her sleep early Thanksgiving Day, November 23, 2006.	1
Sentence	2	She was 87.	0
Sentence	3	Known as the "Jezebel of Jazz," she was one of America's most respected jazz vocalists whose vocal contemporaries included Ella Fitzgerald, Billie Holiday and Sarah Vaughan.	1
Sentence	4	A Chicago native, she gained national recognition while touring with Jazz legends Gene Krupa and Stan Kenton.	1
Sentence	5	Her first national hit was on "Let Me Off Uptown" with Gene Krupa's orchestra, which became a million dollar seller.	0
Sentence	6	Downbeat magazine named her "New Star of the Year" in 1942.	0
Sentence	7	After touring with Stan Kenton and his Orchestra, and recording "And Her Tears Flowed Like Wine," her talent shown as a solo star.	0
Sentence	8	Her style became a foundational influence upon modern jazz recordings.	0
Sentence	9	Her innovative scat style singing and lyrical ballads were recorded on Verve Records in the 1950s.	1
Sentence	10	Her colorfully innovative vocal style was evidenced in motion pictures "The Gene Krupa Story" and "Jazz On A Summer's Day."	0
Sentence	11	Having a close brush with death from heroin addiction in 1967, she also survived alcohol addiction.	1
Sentence	12	She completed her autobiography "High Times, Hard Times" in 1981 and is the subject of a full-length documentary "Anita O'Day - the Life of A Jazz Singer," which has yet to be released.	0
Sentence	13	Her last album, which she recorded at age 85, "Indestructable Anita O'Day," on the Kayo Sterophonics/MRI label, was released last year.	0

Sentence	15	And recollected that "On Tuesday night, she said to me, 'get me out of here.'	0

Sentence	18	She had come back after all of this time.	0
Sentence	19	She really lived a very full and exciting life."	0
Sentence	20	Born Anita Belle Colton O'Day, October 18, 1919, she escaped from a broken home at age 14, and began contesting with touring walk-a-thons popular at the time, and was occasionally asked to sing.	1
Sentence	21	Upon her return to Chicago, she landed her first legitimate singing job at Planet Mars, a Chicago nightclub.	0
Sentence	22	Carl Cons, Down Beat magazine's then-editor, was so impressed with her performance that he invited her to open his new jazz club.	0
Sentence	23	As a showcase for promising jazz talent, The Off-Beat was frequented by such musicians as drummer Gene Krupa, and others.	1
Sentence	24	During one of her performances there in 1941, Krupa recruited her to join his orchestra.	0
Sentence	25	In 1943, Anita left Krupa's band and married professional golfer Carl Hoff.	1
Sentence	26	She later briefly joined clarinetist Woody Herman's band, then reluctantly Stan Kenton's.	0
Sentence	27	Thinking her style wasn't compatible with hers, she was surprised when in 1944 the tune "And Her Tears Flowed Like Wine" became a national hit.	0
Sentence	28	Anita's fierce love of swing beats, conflicted however with Kenton's infatuation with strident rhythms and novelty tunes, and a year later, left over artistic differences.	1
Sentence	29	Her improvisational style, and love of bebop lured her toward those with whom she could hone her talent, and by the late 1940s began her career as a solo jazz vocal artist.	1
Sentence	30	She invited John Poole, a drummer whom she met at the Club Starlite in Los Angeles, to join her.	1
Sentence	31	She once said of John, "If the drummer is no good, I can't make it.	0
Sentence	32	That's why I like John Poole.	0
Sentence	33	He's my favorite drummer."	0
Sentence	34	Their musical affiliation lasted 32 years.	0
Sentence	35	In 1955, Norman Granz signed Anita to his company, Verve records, and her debut album "This is Anita" was the label's first LP.	1
Sentence	36	Though she rarely sang ballads, her interpretation of "A Nightingale Sang in Berkeley Square," was considered so enthralling and fascinating that rocketed her career to new levels.	0
Sentence	37	Her performances with jazz greats Louis Armstrong, Dinah Washington, Thelonious Monk, George Shearling and others were renown.	1
Sentence	38	She became an international star after her performance of  "Jazz on a Summer's Day" at the 1958 Newport Jazz Festival, which later became a documentary film.	0
Sentence	39	Anita recorded 16 albums between 1957 and 1963 with a variety of groups, ranging from small ensembles, big bands to large orchestras.	1
Sentence	40	Her performances' ranged from vibraphonist Cal Tjader to The 3 Sounds, a hard bop trio.	0
Sentence	41	Her first Japanese tour in 1964 was received with acclaim while stateside, the popularity of jazz was decreasing.	0
Sentence	42	Her nonconventional, self-initiated cold-turkey recovery from heroin addiction at a Hawaiian retreat was successful, and she later returned to work.	1

Article	98
Sentence	1	 U.S. Medicare drug benefit cost estimates rise to $558 billion in latest Congressional Budget Office (CBO) estimates.	1
Sentence	2	The CBO estimated that the Medicare Modernization Act, "would result in additional direct spending of about $395 billion over the 2004-2013 period."	1
Sentence	3	The estimate included $552 billion mandatory spending for Medicare Part D, offset by savings of $13 billion from changes to Parts A and B, and "estimated savings of $145 billion in Medicaid and other federal programs because the Part D benefit would reduce spending in those federal programs."	0
Sentence	4	Although the projections only slightly modified the net costs, from $552 billion to $558 billion, the $158 billion in offset from previous estimates were completely removed with a limited justification.	1
Sentence	5	"The estimated savings to Medicaid and other federal programs are incorporated in our baseline projections and are not separately identifiable," the CBO said.	0
Sentence	6	The $552 billion dollar figure is missing from the November 2003 estimates, with a total cost for 2004-2013 presented as single line item of $410 billion as "Prescription Drug Benefit (Title I)."	1
Sentence	7	Over the same period the current estimate, which is categorized differently, lists the total costs for the "Benefits and Mandatory Administrative Costs"  as $779 billion, with Part D. Premiums and payments by States reducing the number by $221 billion to $558 billion.	0
Sentence	8	The report presented two tables: one justifying the prior $395 billion figure, including itemizations for "Savings to Medicaid and Other Federal Programs" totaling $145 billion and "Other Spending Effects" totaling $13 billion, and another presenting the current estimate, which only listed "Savings to Medicaid and Other Federal Programs" and "Other Spending Effects"as being "Not Separately Identifiable."	1
Sentence	9	"This just brings us back to the Bush administration's credibility gap," Rep. Charles Rangel of New York told the L.A. Times.	1
Sentence	10	Medicare is overseen by the House Ways and Means Committee, and Rep. Rangels is the senior Democrat on the committee.	0
Sentence	11	"How can we trust them on Social Security when they did not play straight with the facts on Medicare?"	0
Sentence	12	he said.	0
Sentence	13	Dr. Mark B. McClellan, administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, disagreed, saying "there has been no significant change in the cost of the drug benefit" for the years 2006 - 2015 despite the numbers he brought forward having a cost of $1.2 trillion dollars.	1
Sentence	14	He points to a difference in years covered by his estimates as the reason, and that the numbers represented "gross costs" and did not reflect premiums paid by Medicare beneficiaries, compulsory contributions by states or savings to the Medicaid program.	0

Article	337
Sentence	1	Yesterday, Zomato, a food ordering and restaurant finding company, announced security breach of more than 17 million accounts, via their official blog.	1
Sentence	2	A hacker operating under the alias nclay uploaded evidence to prove they had the stolen data — hashed passwords and emails — for sale, Hackread.com reported.	0
Sentence	3	Zomato later announced they contacted the hacker, who asked Zomato to organise a bug bounty programme.	0
Sentence	4	The food ordering company, with 120 million monthly users, said the payment information of the users was not located with this data and was not leaked.	1
Sentence	5	Zomato said it uses PCI Data Security Standards.	0
Sentence	6	As a security measure, all the passwords of the involved Zomato accounts were reset and all of the accounts were forcibly  logged out from the application and website.	1
Sentence	7	The company said only hashed passwords were compromised.	0
Sentence	8	Hashed passwords are encrypted and, per Zomato, every password had a different "salt", for cryptographic salting was performed before hashing the original password.	1
Sentence	9	A "salt" is a random set of characters added before encryption to make decryption to obtain the original passkey more difficult.	0
Sentence	10	The hashed password itself can not be used to access the account.	1
Sentence	11	In the blog post before contacting the hacker, saying "internal (human) security breach", Zomato suggested this could have happened after a worker's development account was hijacked.	0
Sentence	12	After contacting the hacker, and promising a bug bounty programme on Hackerone, they said, the hacker agreed and removed the stolen data which was put on sale on the dark web.	0

Article	374
Sentence	1	Preliminary results from the National Assessment of Adult Literacy (NAAL), released 15 December 2005 by the US National Center for Education Statistics, indicate gains and losses in literacy among minority adults between 1992 and 2003.	1
Sentence	2	The nationally representative study among US adults age 16 and older found the over-all average prose and document literacy remained relatively unchanged, but quantitative literacy improved 8 points (on a scale of 500.)	1
Sentence	3	Results among minorities were mixed, with White and Asian/Pacific Islander minorities scoring significantly higher than Hispanic or Black ethnicities; Hispanic subjects in particular had sharp decreases in prose and document literacy (-9% and -8%, respectively) and quantitative illiteracy remained unchanged with 50% of subjects scoring at less than basic literacy levels.	0
Sentence	4	The National Assessment of Adult Literacy is the most comprehensive measure of adult literacy in the USA.	1
Sentence	5	The 2003 NAAL, with 19 000 participants, was conducted by the Educational Testing Service, a non-governmental organization which charges for its services.	0
Sentence	6	The survey measured three types of literacy:	1
Sentence	7	In each of these types of literacy the study categorized the subjects into four classes: below basic literacy, basic literacy, intermediate literacy, and proficient literacy.	1
Sentence	8	The break down of literacy was performed across a range of variables, such as ethnicity, gender, age, first language, education, and employment status.	0
Sentence	9	Some of the results were surprising, while others reflect continuing trends in the population.	1
Sentence	10	High proficiency in reading continued to decline between 1992 and 2003 among White subjects, as well as among Hispanics—both down 1%—while Black subjects maintained their level and Asian/Pacific Islanders increased 3%.	1
Sentence	11	Across the ethnicities education level was a greater indicator of reading proficiently with 4.5% of high (secondary) school graduates reading at this level compared with 29% of college graduates and 36% of subjects in graduate studies/degrees.	0
Sentence	12	An important difference between the 2003 survey and the 1992 survey was both in the make-up of the sample and in the inclusion of subjects who were unable to communicate in English or Spanish with the researchers.	1
Sentence	13	By ethnicity, the percentage of Black participants remained largely the same while the percentage of Hispanic and Asian/Pacific Islanders grew significantly and the percentage of White participants was reduced.	0
Sentence	14	The instructions were made available in English and Spanish, although all testing material was exclusively in English, and 3% of participants who were unable to answer basic literacy screening questions took an alternative assessment.	0
Sentence	15	Even so, 2% of the subject group were unable to communicate with researchers at all in English or Spanish (this was down from 3% in 1992.)	0
Sentence	16	According to the National Centre for Education Statistics, the tests are carried out to measure America's progress in the area of adult literacy.	1
Sentence	17	The results are made available to the general public, but are of most interest to researchers, practitioners and policymakers.	0

Article	184
Sentence	1	 File:Lakota Freedom Delegation conference 1.jpg	1
Sentence	2	The Lakota Freedom Delegation, which in December declared that the Lakota people were withdrawing from their treaties with the United States and reasserting their sovereignty as an independent state, is acting without the support of the Treaty Council, the traditional government of the Lakota, Wikinews has learned.	1
Sentence	3	Wikinews spoke with Floyd Looks-For-Buffalo Hand, an Oglala Lakota Treaty Delegate and Elder, also an author and a spiritual leader in the indigenous Lakota religion, and who is also blood uncle to Lakota Freedom Delegation member Canupa Gluha Mani.	1
Sentence	4	The Lakota Freedom Delegation has claimed that, while the BIA-recognized tribal governments of the Lakota have not supported them, the Lakota Freedom Delegation's authority extends from support by the Treaty Council of the Elders of Lakota as well as from the 1974 International Indian Treaty Council.	1
Sentence	5	"There was no treaty withdrawal.	1
Sentence	6	It was three people."	0
Sentence	7	"Russell Means and Duane Martin [Canupa Gluha Mani] and that lady [Phyllis Young], they do not speak for the nation.	1
Sentence	8	You've got to have consensus" among the eight tribes of the Lakota, he said, which the Lakota Freedom Delegation has not obtained.	0
Sentence	9	Mr. Hand stated that he was speaking as a tribal delegate with the consensus of the Oglala Treaty Delegation and his chief, Oliver Red Cloud.	0
Sentence	10	Hand furthermore called the treaty withdrawal event a "publicity stunt" and that furthermore the 1974 meeting was not authorization to act on behalf of the Lakota people.	1
Sentence	11	While Means, Canupa Gluha Mani, and the rest of the delegation "have free speech" and can do as they wish, he said, the Elders of Lakota "stated that they should remove themselves from treaty territory," that is, the Reservations inhabited by the Lakota.	0
Sentence	12	But "they're still living here" (Canupa Gluha Mani has been residing in Asheville, North Carolina since the treaty withdrawal press conference on December 19).	0
Sentence	13	When asked if the above decisions represented the consensus of the whole Treaty Council, Hand stated, "we all do the same because we're all fullbloods.	1
Sentence	14	We all speak our own language."	0
Sentence	15	Hand went on to explain, though, that the Treaty Council was planning to reconsider the Lakota's arrangement with the United States government.	1
Sentence	16	The Treaty Council of all eight Lakota tribes, which will meet on 28–30 January 2008, will consider whether to "sit down to negotiate" with the federal government.	0
Sentence	17	Members of the Lakota Freedom Delegation are expected to take part in that meeting.	0
Sentence	18	European-Americans, Hand said, are "not honoring" the 1851 and 1868 treaties which connected the Lakota to the United States, and noted that the Lakota were the only people to "conquer" the United States during the Indian Wars of the 19th century.	0
Sentence	19	The arrangement with the United States, which he called a "contract", "handcuffs us through the federal programs".	1
Sentence	20	On their own, Hand said, "if we rely on a sovereign nation as a nation, relating to other nations with our economic development I think we can survive."	0
Sentence	21	Hand noted that one possibility under consideration was asserting the right to negotiate independently of the US government with foreign powers in areas such as airport access rights.	0
Sentence	22	The Lakota, he said, would charge foreign airlines half what the United States charges to make use of airports on Lakota soil.	0
Sentence	23	"We can be well off," he argued.	0
Sentence	24	In another contradiction of the Lakota Freedom Delegation's program, Hand said that the Treaty Delegations "don't want technology on our reservation".	1
Sentence	25	One of his concerns was environmentalism.	0
Sentence	26	People of European descent are "taking too much out of Mother Earth", he said, making reference to ongoing environmental effects of uranium mining which has long been a contentious issue on the Lakota reservations.	0
Sentence	27	The Treaty Delegation's goal, he said, is "preserving the land and animals and letting the water remain free."	0
Sentence	28	However, one of the plans of the Lakota Freedom Delegation is to install renewable energy technology on tribal land, such as solar and wind farms.	1
Sentence	29	This follows projects in the past, whereby wind turbines were erected on the Rosebud Reservation.	0
Sentence	30	Such projects would lessen dependence on foreign energy sources, as well as coincide with the Lakota's traditional respect for the environment.	0
Sentence	31	Hand also expressed hope for ethnic solidarity among the non-European peoples of the world.	1
Sentence	32	"All the people of color in this world will go for unity and understanding and peace" if they overthrow the Europeans and establish their own governments, he said.	0

Sentence	2	The mother, while crying, told the Afghan women's association RAWA, "A month ago at 11 o'clock of night armed men entered my house and after beating and threatening me by gun, abducted my only daughter."	1
Sentence	3	She said that it was later found that her daughter had been raped and exchanged for a dog and a sum of money to another person.	0
Sentence	4	The girl's whereabouts are still unknown.	0
Sentence	5	She accused the district chief Malom Zafar Shah and the powerful warlord Commander Mehmood of being responsible for the crime.	1
Sentence	6	The mother told journalists: "I approached [the] human rights office and police but none of them could help to find my daughter.	1
Sentence	7	The district chief himself has 4 daughters but he sold my daughters to others.	0
Sentence	8	With many difficulties and problems I grown up [sic] my 2 daughters, one was previously sold [by him] to a Kandahari man and taken to Pakistan and another was exchanged with a dog.	0
Sentence	9	Please bring them to justice."	0
Sentence	10	Both Malom Zafar Shah and warlord Mehmood are from the "Northern Alliance" and members of Jamiat-e Islami Afghanistan led by Burhanuddin Rabbani (currently member of the Parliament).	1
Sentence	11	They have a long record of such crimes and brutalities against people of Kondoz.	0
Sentence	12	Malom Zafar has been appointed as district chief directly by Qasim Fahim the former defense minister and vice President and now member of Senate.	0
Sentence	13	In an interview with Ariana TV, Malom Zafar rejected all charges against himself and Commander Mehmmod telling "no Jehadi brother is involved in such crimes."	1
Sentence	14	Mohammad Zahir Zafari, chief of the human rights office in Kondoz says, they have tried since a month to find the child but the police are also unable to do anything as powerful people have links to the crime.	1
Sentence	15	He also revealed that his office was threatened a number of times to stop following the case.	0
Sentence	16	Pajhwok Afghan News quoted Zahir Zafari on November 7, - "The only person responsible for the abduction of Sanobar is the warlord Mehmood, who exchanged the girl with a dog which he got from Nimatullah and then sold it for 150,000 Afghanis (US$3000)."	1
Sentence	17	Such crimes happen on a daily basis in Kundoz and other parts of Afghanistan where warlords have established jungle law and have all the key positions in their possession.	1
Sentence	18	Few such cases find their way to the media, with journalists fearful of the consequences of  reporting on such incidents.	1

Article	437
Sentence	1	A lighting failure five minutes from the end interrupted the 2007 AFC Asian Cup Group D match between Korea Republic and Saudi Arabia.	1
Sentence	2	The match, played at the Bung Karno Stadium in Jakarta, Indonesia, was stopped for 27 minutes after the lighting on one half of the stadium suddenly turned off.	1
Sentence	3	At the time of the disruption - 84 minutes 35 seconds played - the match was delicately poised at one goal apiece.	1
Sentence	4	An spokesperson for the Asian Football Confederation has said that the lighting failure was 'due to problems with power around Jakarta city'.	1
Sentence	5	Referee Mark Shield, from Australia, immediately stopped the match after the lights turned out.	1
Sentence	6	Under tournament rules, officials had one hour to get the lights and play restarted before the match would have to be abandoned.	0
Sentence	7	An emergency generator was used to restore some of the knocked-out lights to a sufficient level for playing, allowing Shield to restart play after the lengthy delay.	0
Sentence	8	The match was an eventful one generally, especially after half time.	1
Sentence	9	Both teams played a cautious first half which was devoid of any real scoring opportunities.	0
Sentence	10	However, after the break, Korea went 1-0 ahead through striker Choi Sung-Kuk after sixty-six minutes.	1
Sentence	11	A curling cross from the left-hand wing found the head of Sung-Kuk, who moved in front of the Saudi defender and headed the ball into the bottom right-hand corner of the net.	0
Sentence	12	Eleven minutes later, referee Shield awarded Saudi Arabia a penalty kick after Malek Mouath was adjudged to have been fouled inside the penalty box by a Korean defender.	1
Sentence	13	Captain Yasser Al-Qahtani stepped up and converted to level the scores 1-1 after seventy-seven minutes.	0
Sentence	14	After play was restarted due to the power failure, Saudi Arabia had an excellent chance to win the match with the final kick of the game.	1
Sentence	15	Striker Saad Al Harthi missed a one-on-one opportunity with the Korean goalkeeper, pushing his shot wide.	0
Sentence	16	The draw leaves hosts Indonesia on top of the Group D table after defeating Bahrain 2-1 in the opening match of the group.	1
Sentence	17	In Group C, Iran has come back from a goal down to defeat Uzbekistan 2-1 at the Bukit Jalil Stadium, Kuala Lumpur.	1
Sentence	18	Iran conceded the lead to Uzbekistan on sixteen minutes when Iranian defender Rahman Rezaei scored an own goal.	1
Sentence	19	Trying to head the ball back to his goalkeeper Hassan Roudbarian, Rezaei only managed to head the ball over Roudbarianand into the back of his own net.	0
Sentence	20	The score remained 1-0 until the fifty-fifth minute, when Iran equalised through Seyed Jalal Hosseini.	1
Sentence	21	Hosseini headed a fast-moving corner kick from the right hand side by Mehdi Mahdavikia past Uzbekistan's defence to equalize.	0
Sentence	22	Iran then went ahead after seventy-eight minutes after midfielder Andranik Teymourian provided a through-pass which found Javad Kazemian on the edge of the penalty box.	1
Sentence	23	Kazemian struck his shot sweetly to beat the goalkeeper and made the scoreline 2-1.	0
Sentence	24	No further goals came, however Iranian coach Amir Ghalenoei was sent from the sidelines by the referee due to an indiscretion.	1
Sentence	25	The result puts Iran on three points and at the top of Group C, however they trail China, who defeated Malaysia 5-1 a day prior, on goal difference.	1

Article	233
Sentence	1	Uyghurs are involved in China's largest ethnic clash since March 2008, involving at first perhaps 1,000 and up to 3,000 protestors.	1
Sentence	2	Xinhua, the official news agency, reports that 156 people were killed and 1,080 other people are injured.	0
Sentence	3	The riot began Sunday in Ürümqi, the capital city of the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, in northwestern China.	1
Sentence	4	It began as a protest encouraging authorities to look into a previous violent incident between Uyghurs and Han Chinese in June.	0
Sentence	5	In the June incident, two Uyghur men were reportedly beaten to death by a mob at a Guangdong province toy factory.	0
Sentence	6	A rumour spread that the men had sexually harassed Han Chinese women.	0
Sentence	7	According to Chinese state media, police have arrested a man who allegedly spread the rumour.	0
Sentence	8	The June clash has been cited as the instigating factor to the Sunday riot, which escalated.	0
Sentence	9	Authorities closed down Ürümqi with a population of over 2.3 million and neighbouring cities Monday and Tuesday morning.	1
Sentence	10	Protests had spread to Kashgar by Monday.	0
Sentence	11	Police arriving on the scene tried to quell the unrest with tear gas, water hoses, road blocks, armoured vehicles and armed police patrols.	1
Sentence	12	Curfews were imposed, while cell phone and internet services were cut off.	0
Sentence	13	Rioters were using knives, wooden batons, bricks, stones, and were igniting cars, buses, and buildings on fire.	1
Sentence	14	About 700 people had been detained by police as of Monday evening, 200 stores, over a dozen homes, and more than 250 vehicles were destroyed during the riot.	0
Sentence	15	The changing global economics is affecting the social and economic ethnic tensions in China.	1
Sentence	16	One sentiment is that the "government does bald-faced injustice to Uyghur People," said a Uyghur student.	0
Sentence	17	"Uighurs have suffered for years under racial profiling and unjust government policies that have painted the entire Uyghur population as criminals and terrorists," said Rebiya Kadeer, a Uyghur and human rights proponent based in Washington.	0
Sentence	18	Uyghur demonstrators during this riot were seeking an end to discrimination and not separatism, according to Alim Seytoff, Uyghur American Association spokesperson.	0
Sentence	19	More radical Uyghur separatists have been seeking independence in China.	0
Sentence	20	However, the Han have voiced opposite sentiments.	1
Sentence	21	“What they should do is crack down with a lot of force at first, so the situation doesn’t get worse, so it doesn’t drag out like in Tibet," said a Han woman.	0
Sentence	22	"Their mind is very simple.	0
Sentence	23	If you crack down on one, you’ll scare all of them.	0
Sentence	24	The government should come down harder," she continued.	0
Sentence	25	Uyghurs asked for the release of ordinary citizens who were detained.	1
Sentence	26	On Tuesday morning a small contingent of Uyghur gathered to urge the release of those detained following the Sunday riot.	1
Sentence	27	Later in the day approximately 10,000 Han Chinese took to the streets in Ürümqi with poles, meat cleavers, machetes, bricks, chains and other weapons.	1
Sentence	28	"The Uighurs came to our area to smash things, now we are going to their area to beat them," said a Han Chinese protester.	0
Sentence	29	Police protected some neighborhoods with tear gas and road blocks.	0
Sentence	30	By Tuesday over 1,400 had been detained.	1

Article	18
Sentence	1	File:Civil Rights Mural SMC May 2007.jpg	1
Sentence	2	On Tuesday, the "Bloody Sunday Inquiry" published its report into 1972 British Army killing of fourteen civil rights activists in Northern Ireland.	1
Sentence	3	The Saville Inquiry, a twelve-year-long public inquiry into the fatal shooting, published their 5,000-page report; stating, the deaths were "unjustified".	1
Sentence	4	The events of "Bloody Sunday" in 1972 saw soldiers open fire on civilians during a civil rights march.	1
Sentence	5	Family members and supporters of the victims reacted positively to the report, as they gathering outside the Guildhall in Derry.	0
Sentence	6	"What happened on Bloody Sunday was both unjustified and unjustifiable.	1
Sentence	7	It was wrong", British Prime Minister David Cameron told the House of Commons.	0
Sentence	8	He also said, "[t]he Government is ultimately responsible for the conduct of the armed forces, and for that, on behalf of the Government, indeed on behalf of our country, I am deeply sorry", and that "[t]here is no doubt.	0
Sentence	9	There's nothing equivocal, there are no ambiguities".	0
Sentence	10	Cameron said the Saville report states that those killed did not pose a threat and some of those killed and injured were clearly fleeing or going to help those injured or dying.	1
Sentence	11	Some of the key findings were;	0
Sentence	12	Twenty-seven civil rights activists were shot by the British Army's Parachute Regiment (of which "1 Para" was identified as the regiment mainly responsible) during an illegal Northern Ireland Civil Rights Association (NICRA) march in the Bogside area of Derry in 1972.	1
Sentence	13	The NICRA was an organisation, formed in early 1967, which campaigned against discrimination of the Roman Catholic minority in Northern Ireland and had five key demands: "one man, one vote"; an end to gerrymandering, housing discrimination, public authority discrimination and the abolition of the B Specials police reserve.	0
Sentence	14	In the aftermath of Bloody Sunday, an inquiry by the Lord Chief Justice, Lord Widgery, justified British army actions on the day and claimed that many of the activists were armed with guns and nail bombs.	1
Sentence	15	Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP) leader MP Mark Durkan said, "[t]he families have waited a long time for justice and for a long time the reputations and innocence of their loved ones have been smeared by the findings of Widgery".	0
Sentence	16	The shootings lead to the strengthening of Irish republicans' anti-British army arguments in the Nationalist community and provided the Provisional Irish Republican Army (IRA) with queues of new recruits for its "long war", which resulted in 30 years of The Troubles.	1
Sentence	17	The 12-year inquiry is the longest-running and most expensive public inquiry in British judicial history, costing around £200 million.	1
Sentence	18	Around 2,500 people gave testimony, including 505 civilians, nine experts and forensic scientists, 49 journalists, 245 military personnel, 35 paramilitaries or former paramilitaries, 39 politicians and civil servants, seven priests and 33 Royal Ulster Constabulary officers.	0
Sentence	19	Evidence included 160 volumes of data with an estimated 30 million words, 13 volumes of photographs, 121 audio tapes and 10 video tapes.	0
Sentence	20	The victims included Patrick Doherty (32), Hugh Gilmour (17), Jackie Duddy (17), John Young (17), Kevin McElhinney (17), Michael Kelly (17), Gerald Donaghey (17), William Nash (19), Michael McDaid (20), Jim Wray (22), William McKinney (27) and Bernard "Barney" McGuigan (41).	1
Sentence	21	John Johnston (59) died four months later.	0

Sentence	4	The relay covered more than 1,200 km through 25 cities and counties since its start on October 24.	1
Sentence	5	The organizer of the event, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) held night-time parties in the cities of Ilan, Hualien, Taitung, Pingtung, Kaohsiung, Tainan, Yunlin, Taichung, Miaoli, and Hsinchu as the relay progressed, and finally in Taipei City to welcome the torch relay team.	0

Sentence	8	In addition, the China Unification Promotion Party attempted several aggressive actions but ultimately carried out a peaceful protest.	0
Sentence	9	Protesters had demonstrated previously, on October 24 at the start of the relay.	0

Sentence	11	These were eventually removed by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).	0
Sentence	12	The use of Made in China products was criticized by DPP legislator Kuo-ching Lin after the television reports.	0

Sentence	1	Jaslene Gonzalez is not your typical model.	1
Sentence	2	She rose to fame after winning Cycle 8 of America's Next Top Model, and since then, has been aggressively tapping into the fashion industry.	0

Sentence	7	They were involved in my life everyday.	0

Article	395
Sentence	1	This year's Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded on Monday to Andrew Fire and Craig Mellow, for their research on RNA interference.	1
Sentence	2	47-year old Fire is a professor of pathology and genetics at Stanford University, and Mello, 45, is a professor in Molecular Medicine at the University of Massachusetts.	1
Sentence	3	The statement from the Nobel Assembly of the Karolinska Institute in Sweden said: "This year's Nobel Laureates have discovered a fundamental mechanism for controlling the flow of genetic information."	1
Sentence	4	Fire and Mello's (then at Washington's Carnegie Institution) seminal publication in Nature in 1998 opened the door for "exciting possibilities", the jury in Stockholm added.	0
Sentence	5	RNA interference (or RNAi) is the process of using double stranded RNA fragments which bind and interfere with a specific messenger RNA, so that it's not longer used to make proteins.	1
Sentence	6	It has been recognised as a natural way of gene regulation in plants and animals.	0
Sentence	7	Today, the technology is being used by biomedical scientists to fiddle genes involved in diseases such as cancer, and to prevent infection with hepatitis viruses.	0
Sentence	8	Drs.	1
Sentence	9	Fire and Mello were elected to the U.S. National Academy of Sciences in May 2005, after they received the organisation's Award in Molecular Biology in 2003.	0
Sentence	10	The same year, they got the Wiley Prize in the Biomedical Sciences from Rockefeller University.	0
Sentence	11	Science magazine has dubbed RNAi the 2002 "Breakthrough of the Year", and a top 10 scientific advance in 2003.	0
Sentence	12	They have received many other prizes, such as the Paul Ehrlich and Ludwig Darmstaedter Prize, and Dr. Mello was the inaugural recipient of The Dr. Paul Janssen Award for Biomedical Research by Johnson & Johnson.	0
Sentence	13	Last year, the 10 million Swedish crown prize ($1.37 million, €1.08 million) was awarded to Barry Marshall and Robin Warren for their discovery of the importance of Helicobacter pylori in ulcers and inflammation of the GI tract.	1

Sentence	6	Popular with television viewers in the 1950s and 1960s, Guiding Light fell on hard times, becoming the lowest-rated soap opera on American television in 2007.	1

Sentence	8	The agency urged Rolls-Royce to "address the safety issue and take actions necessary to ensure the safety of flight operations in transport aircraft equipped with Rolls-Royce Trent 900 series engines."	0

Article	1
Sentence	1	 The definition of what is and what is not a planet is being challenged by a newly announced discovery Friday.	1
Sentence	2	Astronomers from the Palomar Observatory near San Diego, California said they found a chunk of ice and rock in the solar system larger than Pluto.	0
Sentence	3	The object, given the temporary generic name of 2003 UB313, is about 9 billion miles away from the sun.	1
Sentence	4	It was first photographed in 2003 using the Gemini Observatory in Hawaii.	0
Sentence	5	But it was an indistinguishable bright spot among a field of stars in an area of the sky where astronomers don't usually look at for planets or planet-type objects.	0
Sentence	6	Solar system bodies found beyond the orbit of Neptune are called "trans-Neptunian objects".	1
Sentence	7	One of them, Pluto, is also classified as a planet.	0
Sentence	8	Up until now all other planet-like discoveries beyond Neptune, including Sedna, found by the same Palomar team in 2004, are called Kuiper Belt objects, or minor planets.	0
Sentence	9	Using a photo taken on January 8, the Palomar team compared it with previous 2003 UB313 photos to triangulate the object's distance, brightness and orbit.	1
Sentence	10	Using mathematical formulas, they found a range of sizes for 2003 UB313, with an estimated average showing the approximate diameter of the new body to be about 2,600 kilometers.	1
Sentence	11	But even at the smallest estimate scientists are certain 2003 UB313 is larger than Pluto's 2,250 kilometer diameter.	0
Sentence	12	To determine size, Scientists deduce the relative size of a solar system object by its brightness, just as one can infer the size of a faraway light bulb if one knows its wattage.	1
Sentence	13	The reflectance of 2003 UB313 is not yet known for sure.	0
Sentence	14	Scientists can not yet tell how much light from the sun is reflected away from its surface, but the amount of light the planet does reflect puts a lower limit on its size.	0
Sentence	15	"Even if it reflected 100 percent of the light reaching it, it would still be as big as Pluto," Michael E. Brown, a professor of planetary astronomy at the California Institute of Technology said in a NASA press release.	1
Sentence	16	"I'd say it's probably one and a half times the size of Pluto, but we're not sure yet of the final size."	0
Sentence	17	"We are 100 percent confident that this is the first object bigger than Pluto ever found in the outer solar system," Brown added.	1
Sentence	18	The object is inclined by a whopping 45 degrees to the main plane of the solar system, where most of the other planets orbit.	1
Sentence	19	That's why it eluded discovery: nobody was looking there until now, Brown said.	0
Sentence	20	Most objects in the solar system are just a few degrees from the main plane of the solar system, called the Ecliptic.	1
Sentence	21	Pluto, which is considered substantially different from the rest of the planets, is only 17 degrees from this main plane.	0
Sentence	22	Astronomers who study the sky for asteroids and comets usually look in the region of the sky that the rest of the planets occupy.	0
Sentence	23	The brightness of this object is just barely fainter than the telescopes from earlier sky surveys were able to identify, so new advances in the making of telescopes has also played a part in this discovery.	1
Sentence	24	Now that the discovery data has been released, the scientists will turn over their work to the International Astronomical Union (IAU), which will review it, classify the object and approve a new name to replace the temporary 2003 UB313.	1
Sentence	25	Sometimes the discoverers of a new planetary body get to choose its name, but not always.	1
Sentence	26	"We have a name we really like, and we want it to stick," Brown told reporters at a press conference.	0
Sentence	27	He said the team has submitted the name to the IAU but would not disclose their choice.	0
Sentence	28	In the 2004 naming of Sedna, Brown noted objects found in the Kuiper Belt are usually named after deities of the Underworld.	0
Sentence	29	The astronomers have been using a code name of sorts for the discovery.	1
Sentence	30	The tongue-in-cheek nickname  is "Xena" after the fictional main character of the television series of the same name.	0
Sentence	31	"Because we always wanted to name something Xena," Dr. Brown said in a New York Times report.	0
Sentence	32	There has been controversy in the scientific community about what is and what is not a planet.	1
Sentence	33	Some purists insist the Solar system has only eight planets and that Kuiper Belt object including Pluto, Sedna and 2003 UB313 cannot be listed among the major planets.	0
Sentence	34	A minor furor erupted when the IAU suggested removing Pluto from the pantheon of planets a few years ago.	1
Sentence	35	Because of that Pluto's status as a "planet" in addition to being a Kuiper Belt object was cemented.	0
Sentence	36	But with the discovery of 2003 UB313 the "planet or not" debate may rekindle.	0
Sentence	37	"Pluto has been a planet for so long that the world is comfortable with that," Brown said in the teleconference.	1
Sentence	38	"It seems to me a logical extension that anything bigger than Pluto and farther out is a planet."	0
Sentence	39	Offering additional justification, Brown said 2003 UB313 appears to be surfaced with methane ice, as is Pluto.	1
Sentence	40	That's not the case with other large Kuiper Belt objects, however.	0
Sentence	41	"This object is in a class very much like Pluto," he said.	1
Sentence	42	The new "10th planet" was not the only new discovery in the Kuiper Belt this past week.	1
Sentence	43	José-Luis Ortiz at the Sierra Nevada Observatory in Spain announced the discovery of an object called 2003 EL61.	0
Sentence	44	This object, thought to be larger than Sedna, is the brightest trans-Neptune object next to Pluto.	0
Sentence	45	Although some news media confused the discovery of 2003 EL61 with 2003 UB313, they are different objects.	1
Sentence	46	2003 EL61 is so bright, it can be seen with high-end amateur-grade telescopes equipped with CCD cameras.	1
Sentence	47	Although this second discovery may not be as large as 2003 UB313, scientists have confirmed that 2003 EL61 has its own moon.	0

Article	183
Sentence	1	On Thursday, Congress turned down the "Net Neutrality Amendment" to the Communications Opportunity, Promotion, and Enhancement Act (COPE Act) 269-152.	1
Sentence	2	The COPE Act is designed to make it easier for telecommunications companies to offer cable TV service and strengthen competition.	1
Sentence	3	Proponents hope it would lower the price of high-speed Internet for consumer by enabling Internet service providers to bundle phone, data, video and mobile phone services.	0
Sentence	4	The act is the first major telecommunications bill to come before Congress in over a decade, and it passed by 321-101 vote on Thursday.	0
Sentence	5	Portions of the "Net Neutrality" amendment to the COPE Act sought to assure that communication companies who provide Internet services treated all data delivery passing through their connections equally.	1
Sentence	6	It specified that each broadband provider has the duty "not to block, impair, degrade, discriminate against, or interfere with the ability of any person to use a broadband connection to access, use, send, receive, or offer lawful content, applications, or services over the Internet."	0
Sentence	7	The amendment's passage would have prevented AT&T, Verizon, Comcast and other broadband providers from charging content providers like Google, Yahoo, Amazon or eBay for priority access to their networks.	0
Sentence	8	Democrats were largely in favour of the legislation with 140 Ayes and 58 Noes, whereas only 11 Republicans voted for the measure, with 211 against.	0
Sentence	9	House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi argued that "The imposition of additional fees for Internet content providers would unduly burden Web-based small businesses and start-ups," and that "They would also hamper communications by noncommercial users, those using religious speech, promoting civic involvement and exercising First Amendment freedoms."	1
Sentence	10	The phone companies and their Congressional allies argued that the restrictions in the amendment would discourage investment in upgrading networks.	1
Sentence	11	Chief technology officer for BellSouth William L. Smith told the Washington Post that telephone companies should be able to charge companies for having their content load faster than that of competitors.	0
Sentence	12	"If I go to the airport, I can buy a coach standby ticket or a first-class ticket," Smith said.	0
Sentence	13	"In the shipping business, I can get two-day air or six-day ground."	0
Sentence	14	The legislation has been subject to intense lobbying by telecommunication companies on one side, and content providers on the other.	1
Sentence	15	The bill is due to be discussed next in the Senate, where lobbying efforts from both sides are expected to intensify.	0
Sentence	16	The White House said that it supports the current bill.	0

Sentence	1	Millions may starve in Kenya, Somalia, Ethiopia, and Djibouti in East Africa, because of extreme drought, combined with inequalities built into mechanisms for distributing food, according to the analysis made by Amartya Sen, who was awarded the Bank of Sweden Prize in Economic Sciences in 1998.	1
Sentence	2	War in parts of the region is an extra exacerbating factor.	0
Sentence	3	The countries need immediate food, water, seeds and any other agricultural product, according to the Rome-based Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), which reports that millions of people are on the brink of starvation due to the recent severe droughts that have been devastating the area.	1
Sentence	4	"The whole area is affected," FAO representative Shukri Ahmed said.	1
Sentence	5	"The situation is deteriorating."	0
Sentence	6	Local newspaper reports gave an official death toll at 30 famine-related deaths, said Mr Ahmed.	0
Sentence	7	Many had not expected that the area's dry season would be as severe as it has been, and did not anticipate the effects.	1
Sentence	8	Others, such as Yves Engler, expect famines and massive starvation to continue in the region as long as the IMF continues to influence economic policies in the region.	1
Sentence	9	Yves Engler has claimed, consistently with Amartya Sen's analysis, that the IMF is responsible for worsening or actually creating famine in Malawi (2002), Ethiopia (2003) and Niger (2005).	0

Sentence	13	What makes the region's situation even more grave, is that the rainy season failed to aid in the production of much needed crops.	0
