Article	396
Sentence	1	John C. Mather of NASA and George F. Smoot of Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory shared the 2006 Nobel Prize for Physics for "their discovery of the blackbody form and anisotropy of the cosmic microwave background radiation."	1
Sentence	2	The Nobel Prize Committee cited the physicists for their work on the Cosmic Background Explorer (COBE) project.	1
Sentence	3	COBE revealed fluctuations in faint microwave signals from space that are thought to be remnants of the Big Bang.	0
Sentence	4	Although the precise origin of the fluctuations in the cosmic microwave background is not yet clear, they may represent clumps in the very early universe that led to the galaxies seen today.	1
Sentence	5	Prior to the COBE map of the universe, it was unclear why the universe contained stars and galaxies rather than an evenly distributed dust cloud.	1
Sentence	6	Theorists had predicted that a sensitive measurement of microwaves from the sky would reveal minute temperature fluctuations, which represent variations in the density of matter in the early universe.	0
Sentence	7	The denser portions served as seeds for galaxies that formed later.	0
Sentence	8	COBE was the first experiment sensitive enough to confirm the predicted temperature variations encoded in the map of the microwave background.	0
Sentence	9	The initial discovery of the Cosmic Microwave Background by Arno Penzias and Robert Wilson led to their award of the 1978 Nobel Prize in physics.	1
Sentence	10	Although they measured the approximate temperature of the universe to be about 3.5 kelvins, their ground-based microwave telescope could not pick out the detail available to COBE.	0

Article	55
Sentence	1	A retired biologist from Florida State University has captured photos of a rodent in Laos which scientists thought was extinct for 11 million years.	1
Sentence	2	Science education professor emeritus, David Redfield and bird watcher, Uthai Treesucon, were able to catch the rodent, but only after failing to do so four times.	0
Sentence	3	They returned it to the wild after they took photos and a video of the rodent.	0
Sentence	4	"We went to Laos specifically to find this animal.	1
Sentence	5	We were extremely fortunate in so many ways to be able to do this.	0
Sentence	6	We photographed it with stills and a movie camera.	0
Sentence	7	Then we took it back to its habitat and released it.	0
Sentence	8	It's easily one of the most gratifying experiences of my life, and I hope these pictures will help in some way to prevent the loss of this marvellous animal," said Redfield.	0
Sentence	9	The rodent, whose scientific name is Laonastes aenigmamus, is called Laotian rock rat and known to local villagers as 'kha-nyou'.	1
Sentence	10	It belongs to the family Diatomyidae.	0
Sentence	11	It was photographed in Laos near the village of Doy, in May 2006.	0
Sentence	12	The rodent resembles a tree shrew or a squirrel.	0
Sentence	13	It walks like a duck and has angled feet that allow it to climb trees.	0

Sentence	15	The rodent has since been named as a new species.	0

Sentence	17	This is a truly exciting discovery," said Mary Dawson , the curator at the Carnegie Museum of Natural History in Pittsburgh, who confirmed the findings.	0
Sentence	18	The rodent was able to be officially named after researchers compared bones from fossils of the rodent found in Asia, to bones of a recently found Laotian rock rat.	1

Sentence	1	The United States government officially charged 11 individuals today for the theft and sale of over 40 million credit and debit card numbers.	1
Sentence	2	The card numbers were stolen from nine US retailers including Barnes & Noble.	0
Sentence	3	The indictment includes computer intrusion, conspiracy, identity theft and fraud.	1
Sentence	4	This case is suspected to be the largest computer hacking and identity theft case ever to be prosecuted by the US Justice Department.	0
Sentence	5	The 11 people charged include three from the US, three from the Ukraine, two from China, and one each from Estonia and Belarus.	1
Sentence	6	The remaining person is only known by an alias, and his/her place of origin is not known.	0

Sentence	9	According to the Justice Department, after hacking into wireless computer networks of the victim companies, the group would install a sniffer program to identify card numbers and steal information required for use of the numbers.	1
Sentence	10	The compiled information was then stored in computer servers owned by the group.	0
Sentence	11	—Michael Mukasey, Attorney General	1
Sentence	12	The credit card numbers were then sold online to the customers who would "cash out" the numbers by scanning them on to the magnetic strips of blank cards.	1
Sentence	13	The funds earned by the group from the sale of the numbers were either transferred to internet currencies where the money was laundered, or transferred directly to eastern European banks.	1

Sentence	15	Several of these retailers belong to TJX Companies.	0

Sentence	4	When users click an email attachment, their PCs become infected with destructive, self-replicating software.	1

Sentence	4	"Sweeps" occurs four times a year and helps networks and independent affiliates determine how much a fixed amount of time for commercial advertisement will cost (the higher the ratings, the more revenue for the networks selling the time to advertisers).	0
Sentence	5	On the whole, Family Guy averaged a 6.3 rating in the overnights as posted by Zap2It.	1
Sentence	6	While the overnight ratings are fairly accurate, the numbers are preliminary and are subject to minor change.	0
Sentence	7	One ratings point is equal to 1,096,000 households, as there are now 109,600,000 households in the United States with at least one television.	0
Sentence	8	This translates into a little more than 6.9 million households whose sets were tuned into Family Guy, as recorded by the sample of "Nielsen families," who record their viewing habits and contribute to the ratings process the US uses.	0
Sentence	9	The use of the word "share" in the article means that it is the rough percentage of viewers with their sets on at that hour tuning into a certain program.	0
Sentence	10	For example, nine percent of viewers in the United States with their televisions on at 9 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time were tuned to Family Guy.	0
Sentence	11	This only added up to a 9 household share for the hour, compared to an 11 share for Law & Order: Criminal Intent on NBC, a 14 share for a CBS Hallmark Hall of Fame movie of the week (traditionally only aired during the key sweeps periods), and a 23 share for the aforementioned Desperate Housewives.	1
Sentence	12	Averaged with the performance of American Dad, a cartoon produced by Family Guy creator Seth MacFarlane, FOX earned a mere 5.8 rating/9 share for the hour.	0

Article	8
Sentence	1	Asteroid 2004 XP14, a half-mile wide chunk of hard rock travelling at 40 000 miles an hour, will miss the Earth by a few hundred thousand miles, Monday.	1
Sentence	2	Dr David Asher from the Armagh Observatory in Northern Ireland said if the rock, discovered in 2004, were to hit the Earth the result would be devastating.	1
Sentence	3	"It would probably be big enough to wipe out a small country," he said.	0
Sentence	4	Amateur astronomers with 6-inch telescopes would be able to follow the speeding space debris in Europe and North America at its closest approach to the planet at 0425 UTC.	1
Sentence	5	At this time it would be at a safe distance of 268,624 miles from Earth - closer to the Earth than the Moon would be at its farthest extent in its orbit.	1
Sentence	6	2004 XP14 is named as a Potentially Hazardous Asteroid (PHA), along with 782 known others by Astronomers at the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory at Harvard.	1
Sentence	7	Zipping about in the solar system no PHAs have yet been found on direct collision course with the Earth.	1
Sentence	8	Still, "For something of this size to come this close is unusual," said Don Yeomans, the head of NASA's Near Earth Object Program."	0
Sentence	9	An expert at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California said it was the closest approach by such a massive object for over 80 years - since 1925.	1
Sentence	10	Before 2004 XP14's exact orbital path around the sun was known with more precision, there were concerns it would hit the Earth.	1
Sentence	11	In the near future Jon Giorgini said such cosmic uncertainty would be much less and the public less alarmed.	1

Article	394
Sentence	1	Today marks the beginning of the 2006 Māori Electoral Option.	1
Sentence	2	The Māori Option process is held by law every five years following the Census, giving voters of Māori descent the choice of being on the general roll or the Māori roll.	0
Sentence	3	Once Māori electors have decided which roll they are on, the Representation Committee will begin the process of redrawing the electoral boundaries.	0
Sentence	4	The Māori roll does not generally affect the proportionality of the Parliament, which is determined by the party vote (see Electoral system of New Zealand).	1
Sentence	5	However the size of the Māori roll does determine how many Māori seats there are, and it is possible (through what is known as an overhang) for a party to win more seats than its share of all votes should allow.	0
Sentence	6	Also if a party wins a seat, it does not have to meet the 5% party vote threshold to be represented in Parliament.	0
Sentence	7	The Māori Party benefited both ways from the Māori seats in the 2005 election.	0
Sentence	8	National Party leader Dr. Don Brash said the option was promoting a "racially-divided electoral system" and National accused the Government of state-sanctioned separatism.	1
Sentence	9	Brash says getting rid of the Māori Seats is an important policy for his party and that the taxpayer should not have to pay the $4.5 million bill.	1
Sentence	10	Māori Party co-leader, Tariana Turia said that National may need the Māori Party after the next election, and that she is "sick to death" of political opportunism.	1

Sentence	7	In his judgement, he wrote that "the fair use of a copyrighted work for the purposes of criticism and commentary is not an infringement of copyright".	0

Sentence	3	For nineteen years, the USC Libraries Scripter Award has honored "writers for the best achievement in adaptation among English-language films released during the previous year and based on a book, novella or short story."	1
Sentence	4	While there are many awards for either screenwriting in general, or adapted screenwriting, the Scripter is the only award to recognize both the screenwriters and the original authors.	1
Sentence	5	The titles were selected by committee, from a list of forty-five eligible films.	1
Sentence	6	The committee is made of Writers Guild of America members (including some Academy Award-winning screenwriters and Academy Award-nominated screen writers), authors, film industry executives, USC faculty, the dean of the USC Libraries, and selected members of the Friends of the USC Libraries, the sponsor of the event.	0
Sentence	7	Previous screenwriters and authors honored include the teams behind Capote, Million Dollar Baby, The Hours, A Beautiful Mind, L.A.	1
Sentence	8	Confidential, The English Patient and Schindler's List.	0

Sentence	5	If it is an obvious form of resistance, then we have to control it so it doesn't cause any disorder in the country."	0
Sentence	6	In a comment to the Bangkok Post, Thai army Colonel Winthai Suwaree shared a similar sentiment: "[The junta] must look at [the protester's] intention, what they want to communicate and surrounding circumstances".	0
Sentence	7	Following the ousting of Thailand's elected government in reportedly the fourteenth coup experienced by the country since the adoption of constitutional monarchy in 1932, the country remains affected by a curfew spanning midnight to 4am, with only Phuket, Koh Samui and Pattaya exempted, as they are beach resorts frequented by tourists, a group for whom the junta made the move in a bid to avoid adverse effects to the country's tourist industry.	1
Sentence	8	Nonetheless, in the wake of the coup, the United States Department of State (DoS) advised "U.S. citizens reconsider any non-essential travel to Thailand, particularly Bangkok".	1
Sentence	9	The DoS also informed US citizens to stay away from groups of protestors, citing that "even demonstrations that are meant to be peaceful can turn confrontational and escalate into violence."	0
Sentence	10	Other restrictions placed on citizens by the junta include internet censorship and restrictions on television broadcasts.	0
Sentence	11	Also banned were assemblies of five or more people with political intent.	0
Sentence	12	Solitary displays of the gesture was among a few forms of protest utilized by the Thai people in Bangkok on Sunday, amid the placement of almost 6000 soldiers and police officers by the junta in an effort to suppress protests.	1
Sentence	13	Other displays of defiance included protestors banding together in flash mobs or peacefully walking through the central shopping district donning masks in an attempt to bypass security forces stationed there.	0
Sentence	14	The gesture finds its origins in The Hunger Games series, where it was a sign of thanks, admiration, and farewell to a loved one, later gaining significance, in the second book Catching Fire, as a symbol of rebellion against the totalitarian government of Panem.	1
Sentence	15	Protesters, however, have found their own ways of deriving meaning behind the gesture, with some reportedly interpreting it as standing for liberté, égalité, fraternité, values popularized by the French Revolution.	0
Sentence	16	A purported alternative interpretation by protesters held the gesture stood for freedom, election, and democracy.	1
Sentence	17	Still others have created a photo montage of the gesture with a picture from the source movie, which circulated online, with the caption "1.	0
Sentence	18	No Coup, 2.	0
Sentence	19	Liberty, 3.	0
Sentence	20	Democracy" written on the three extended fingers.	0
Sentence	21	Manik Sethisuwan has taken to Twitter with this message: "Dear #HungerGames.	0
Sentence	22	We've taken your sign as our own.	0
Sentence	23	Our struggle is non-fiction.	0
Sentence	24	Thanks."	0
Sentence	25	Sombat Boonngam-anong, a social activist who has made efforts to rally the Thai people in continued protest, offered his own interpretation of the gesture on Facebook.	1
Sentence	26	"Raising three fingers has become a symbol in calling for fundamental political rights".	0
Sentence	27	Sombat belongs to the "Red Shirts", a protest group which has supported Shinawatra's government and the earlier government of Thaksin Shinawatra, her brother, and conducted protests amid prosecution by the junta.	0
Sentence	28	Sombat advocated a form of silent protest, raising of their right arms, "3 fingers, 3 times a day" for 30 seconds at 9 a.m., 1 p.m., and 5 p.m., in public locations where police officers and the military are absent.	0
Sentence	29	"Let's escalate the anti-coup movement three times a day together," said Sombat.	0
Sentence	30	Weerachon expressed awareness of the gesture's origins, stating "We know it comes from the movie, and let's say it represents resistance against the authorities.	1
Sentence	31	[...] If a single individual raises three fingers in the air, we are not going to arrest him or her.	0
Sentence	32	But if it is a political gathering of five people or more, then we will have to take some action.	0
Sentence	33	If it persists, then we will have to make an arrest."	0
Sentence	34	On Sunday, protestors were reportedly detained for that reason.	0
Sentence	35	The decision to criminalize displays of the gesture have drawn the criticism of Human Rights Watch, stating it expresses "a mindset that views human rights with disdain, and sees youthful defiance as the enemy."	1
Sentence	36	Human Rights Watch's Asia director, Brad Adams, remarked: "The Thai military's assault on basic human rights has apparently grown to not only target peaceful protesters but now also silent ones as well — since now just holding up an arm with a three-finger salute is enough to earn the junta's ire".	0
Sentence	37	The National Council for Peace and Order has stated it imposed military rule over the country due to political deadlock resulting from demonstrations spanning seven months, which occasionally erupted into violence.	1
Sentence	38	Last year, on the volatile political situation in Thailand, scholar Nicholas Farrelly wrote in the Australian Journal of International Affairs: "Each year, Thailand tends to experience at least one period of frenzied coup speculation.	0

Article	154
Sentence	1	The  Large Hadron Collider (LHC) that started preliminary experiments on September 10, 2008 in  CERN, Geneva, and the planned  International Linear Collider (ILC) will carry out a series of experiments in the future to validate the  standard model of  particle physics.	1
Sentence	2	The model predicts that  Higgs boson particles gives mass to all fundamental particles and explains the existence of  dark matter, or invisible matter in between galaxies.	0
Sentence	3	The LHC is a 27 kilometer long circular high energy  particle accelerator which took more than 20 years and USD $9 billion to build.	1
Sentence	4	In the next few weeks the machine will collide opposing beams of  protons charged with approximately 7 TeV of energy resulting in cataclysmic conditions that will mimic the beginning of time, a re-creation of the  Big Bang.	0
Sentence	5	An upgraded version of the LHC was announced, nicknamed the "super LHC".	1
Sentence	6	The new accelerator will perform ten times the number of collisions as the current LHC over the same time.	0
Sentence	7	The upgrade will feature a new injection system and enhanced detectors to cope with the increase in data packets from collisions.	0
Sentence	8	The bigger International Linear Collider, nicknamed "Einstein's telescope", is planned by the International Technology Recommendation Panel (ITRP).	1
Sentence	9	The ILC will have a collision energy of 500 GeV and will collide  electrons with particles of  antimatter, called  positrons, along a 30-40 km completely straight tunnel.	0
Sentence	10	The ILC's two giant "guns" pointing at each other would be able to accelerate electrons and positrons to near-light speeds before smashing them together.	0
Sentence	11	"The LHC smashes protons together to discover new particles but also generates lots of debris that obscures the fine detail.	1
Sentence	12	The ILC would be a much cleaner machine and tell us far more about their real nature."	0
Sentence	13	says  Brian Foster, professor of experimental physics at Oxford University and European director of the project.	0
Sentence	14	The host country for the ILC has not yet been chosen but it is planned to have the machine constructed by late 2010.	0
Sentence	15	The new machine will cost an estimated USD $7 billion to build.	0
Sentence	16	Physicists hope that ILC might be able to resolve some of the questions raised by Einstein's theories of relativity.	0

Article	64

Sentence	19	The arrangement with the United States, which he called a "contract", "handcuffs us through the federal programs".	1
Sentence	20	On their own, Hand said, "if we rely on a sovereign nation as a nation, relating to other nations with our economic development I think we can survive."	0

Sentence	23	"We can be well off," he argued.	0
Sentence	24	In another contradiction of the Lakota Freedom Delegation's program, Hand said that the Treaty Delegations "don't want technology on our reservation".	1
Sentence	25	One of his concerns was environmentalism.	0
Sentence	26	People of European descent are "taking too much out of Mother Earth", he said, making reference to ongoing environmental effects of uranium mining which has long been a contentious issue on the Lakota reservations.	0
Sentence	27	The Treaty Delegation's goal, he said, is "preserving the land and animals and letting the water remain free."	0
Sentence	28	However, one of the plans of the Lakota Freedom Delegation is to install renewable energy technology on tribal land, such as solar and wind farms.	1
Sentence	29	This follows projects in the past, whereby wind turbines were erected on the Rosebud Reservation.	0
Sentence	30	Such projects would lessen dependence on foreign energy sources, as well as coincide with the Lakota's traditional respect for the environment.	0

Article	11
Sentence	1	Four years ago, on February 9, a major Polish newspaper, Gazeta Wyborcza published a report detailing a hoax in Polish Wikipedia entitled Henryk Batuta.	1
Sentence	2	The author of the report was Konrad Godlewski; several weeks later, Godlewski began editing Polish Wikipedia.	0
Sentence	3	The results of his work include one featured article – pismo chińskie (Polish for "Chinese character") – as well as various articles relating to China.	0

Sentence	6	BATUTA stands for "Bezwzględna Akcja Troskliwego Uźródławiania Tysięcy artykłów", roughly translated as "Ruthless Action of Carefully Adding References to Thousands of Articles".	0
Sentence	7	((Wikinews))  You are the author of the first news story about the Henryk Batuta hoax, uncovered four years ago in the Polish Wikipedia.	1
Sentence	8	Do you remember when did the authors of the hoax first come to you?	0
Sentence	9	Was it just before the publication or earlier?	0
Sentence	10	The hoax was uncovered on January 20 and the story was published on February 9, so there was a period of time between those two dates...	0
Sentence	11	((Konrad Godlewski)) I found them myself.	1
Sentence	12	Accidentally.	0
Sentence	13	I was looking for new, interesting stories about the Internet.	0

Sentence	15	Step by step, I had traced that person.	0

Sentence	26	It was easy to notice the hoax was created by really smart people.	0
Sentence	27	Testing Wikipedia was one of the aspects of this entire thing.	0
Sentence	28	The second one was the attitude towards streets and generally Poland's communist past.	1
Sentence	29	As one could easily guess, Batuta's Army had rather right-wing political views, most probably close to IPN [e.d.	0

Sentence	31	And there was a third reason.	1
Sentence	32	As I'm sure you remember, in the 90s, conspiracy theories concerning Jews were popular in Poland.	0
Sentence	33	As some of the people of such origin had changed their names, the conspiracy theory made people see Jews nearly everywhere.	0
Sentence	34	Such lists were printed on paper and later they got published on the Internet.	0
Sentence	35	((WN)) It's a bit strange.	1

Sentence	37	((KG)) Not all right-wing people are uneducated individuals with antisemitic views.	1
Sentence	38	((WN)) The same IP number (which is dynamic but from a narrow range) which was used to create the hoax, is still being used today to edit Wikipedia.	1

Sentence	75	There are mistakes in respected encyclopedias and books as well.	0

Sentence	77	My favorite example is the one about Michał Boym, Polish Jesuit and one of the first sinologists.	1
Sentence	78	He had done a great job with his descriptions of Chinese plants and animals.	0
Sentence	79	His works were later published in Europe.	0
Sentence	80	Sometimes his text were stolen from him and published under other people's names.	0
Sentence	81	There was a case of "green-furred turtle".	0

Sentence	83	In fact it was a kind of seaweed growing on the turtle's shell.	0
Sentence	84	Boym described it in his Latin text as "viridium".	0
Sentence	85	And printers from Vienna made it "vindium" which can be translated as "floating in air".	0
Sentence	86	This slight typing mistake made people in the West believe there were flying turtles in China.	0
Sentence	87	What's more, there were pictures showing this unusual thing.	0

Sentence	89	((KG)) That's because Wikipedia's articles are the best example of memetics at work.	1

Article	393
Sentence	1	November 5, is Guy Fawkes Night.	1
Sentence	2	On this day, 401 years ago there was an attempt to blow up the British parliament.	0
Sentence	3	Since that time, Guy Fawkes day is celebrated by bonfires, fireworks and the parading of effigies called "guys".	1
Sentence	4	The event is not only celebrated in the United Kingdom, but other Commonwealth countries including New Zealand, South Africa, Newfoundland, Bahamas, Saint Kitts and formerly Australia.	1
Sentence	5	Britons celebrate a national day of thanksgiving that the Gunpowder plot did not destroy their king and parliament.	1
Sentence	6	But as tradition goes, the oppression that Roman Catholics felt was always de-emphasised.	0
Sentence	7	This year sees rising opposition to the traditional fireworks and bonfires celebrations.	1
Sentence	8	A smog warning has been issued for London on the 5th and British Labour MP Barry Sheerman called for the event to be scrapped.	0
Sentence	9	The Gunpowder Treason and plot;I know of no reasonwhy Gunpowder TreasonShould ever be forgot.	1
Sentence	10	—Popular British rhyme in memory of the Gunpowder Plot	1
Sentence	11	The Gunpowder Plot of 1605 was a failed attempt by a few radical Roman Catholics to kill King James I of England, his family, and most of the Protestant aristocracy in a single attack by blowing up the Houses of Parliament during the State Opening.	1
Sentence	12	The conspirators had then planned to abduct the royal children, not present in Parliament, and incite a revolt in the Midlands.	0
Sentence	13	The plot occurred during the long-running religious battle that followed King Henry VIII's break from Rome in 1534.	1
Sentence	14	Far from helping their fellow Catholics avoid religious persecution, the plotters put many loyal Catholics in a difficult position.	1
Sentence	15	Before this period Catholicism had been associated with Spain and the Inquisition but after the plot it also became thought of as treasonous to be Catholic.	0
Sentence	16	Fawkes was hired to do the "dirty work".	1
Sentence	17	He entered the Roman Catholic faith at the age of nine, when his mother married a Roman Catholic after the death of his father.	0
Sentence	18	As a soldier who went to war in the Netherlands, Fawkes was noted for bravery; he was one of the last to hear of the plot, and rushed into it before knowing the details.	0
Sentence	19	The plot was actually planned by Robert Catesby, whose father had been imprisoned for refusing to convert to the Anglican Church.	1
Sentence	20	He started his planning two years previously in 1603.	0
Sentence	21	But he needed money and ammunition, which forced him to confide in at least 13 people.	0
Sentence	22	One of these was Francis Tresham, a brother-in-law of Lord Monteagle, and a member of the House of Lords	0
Sentence	23	The plot failed when one of the conspirators warned his brother-in-law not to attend the House of Lords, who, in turn, set off the alarm that resulted in the ringleaders, including Guy Fawkes, being captured and executed.	1
